Award.AwardTitle: Vertical-Axis Wind Turbine Blade Vibration Modeling for Improved Reliability

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Meeting the goal of 20 percent US energy by wind by 2030 will require a diverse fleet of wind energy harvesters. Wind turbines of various styles and of increasing size will need to be installed in a variety of environments including off shore. Maintenance and repair of very large turbines can be costly and involve significant down time, thereby challenging the development of affordable wind energy. Currently, horizontal-axis wind turbines (HAWTs) are the most popular type, with vertical-axis wind turbines (VAWTs) being the next most common. One thing that has hindered the development of VAWTs is their reputation for having vibration and fatigue problems. This reputation was established well before the development of modern blade materials. But VAWTs have some important advantages. These include independence of wind direction, reduced tower size, lower center of mass, and lower generator placement. Furthermore, HAWT size may be limited by gravity. Also, VAWT efficiency improves when placed in wind-farm arrays. Thus, VAWTs may turn out to be better for some applications, including large off-shore installations, and are therefore getting renewed interest. To date, VAWTs have been modeled in much less depth than HAWTs. These circumstances all converge to the need for better models for VAWTs, including VAWT blade vibration. The purpose of this work is to develop a model for VAWT blade vibration, and to use the model to understand the role of VAWT blade parameters on vibration, to enable the design of reliable VAWTs in the future.

In this work, vibration models of H-rotor VAWT blades will be formulated. The simple geometry of H-rotor blades allows the work to focus on the complexity of the mechanics of VAWT function. The model will include nonlinear beam theory and a semi-empirical model of the nonlinear aerodynamic forces. Preliminary insight into the model suggests the existence of parametric and direct excitation, and nonlinearity, all of which together can interact to produce a variety of resonances and instabilities. Reduced-order modeling and asymptotic analysis will lead to identification of resonances and instabilities. Critical cases will be simulated numerically in more depth. The result will be an understanding of the mechanisms of resonances and instabilities of VAWT blades, as well as the role of parameters, leading to design recommendations for increased reliability, reduced maintenance costs, and less down time.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The vibrations of vertical-axis wind-turbine (VAWT) blades were studied to obtain understanding that will help improve reliability.  We focused on Darrieus, or lift-type, VAWTs.  A mechanics model of the turbine shows that while the VAWT rotor spins in the oncoming wind, the lift force goes through cycles of outward and inward directions on the blade relative to the center of rotation.  Hence, the VAWTs undergo strong forced vibration excitation.  We derived a vibration model for straight-bladed giromill/H-rotor turbines and showed that such structures endure spin softening, meaning they get structurally softer as the rotation rate increases.  The blade’s centrifugal equilibrium deformation increases with speed, and its natural frequency decreases.  This puts limits on the size of the blades, and demands increasing structural supports for larger blades.  We then studied curved Darrieus wind turbine blades.  Finite-element analyses show that these blades have spin stiffening, which is a preferable property.  We formulated a beam-based model of the curved blades and cross checked it against the finite-element model.  The planar beam-based model and the finite-element model were consistent in the prediction of the modal frequencies of the blades.  The beam-based model is beneficial for “reduced-order modeling”, which facilitates analytical studies of the vibration behavior and will help reveal the role of parameters in the vibration behavior.  Simulation studies on the giromill blade model with a airfoil-based aeroelastic force law showed the existence of parametric excitation in both the stiffness and the damping due to aeroelastic effects.  Parametric stiffness is known to incite instabilities and resonance amplification.  We studied the effects of the parametric damping on the transient vibrations.  Parametric damping can also induce instabilities, and reduce the effective energy dissipation in the vibrations.  Continuing studies address the combination of parametric stiffness and damping in transient and steady-state vibration.

INTELLECTUAL MERIT:  

The turbine blade modeling was formulated from descriptions of the deformation of flatwise and edgewise bending, axial extension, and torsion, using fundamental notions of strain and kinetic energy.  The energy has terms arising from simple assumptions about bending and torsion energy, as well as some nonintuitive terms.  Modal analysis of the in-plane (flatwise) beam-based blade model was consistent with finite-element models.  The beam-based model enables a mode-based reduced-order modeling analysis, which is very useful for studying roles of parameters, and for computationally efficient simulation studies.  Such studies help the choice of parameters for detailed computations of specific cases. 

Since the aeroelastic effects lead to parametric stiffness and damping, we used a Floquet-based analysis to approximate the transient-vibration solution and study the stability of cyclic damping and combined cyclic damping and stiffness.  The stability characteristics of the cyclic damping case have trends similar to those of cyclic stiffness.  Characteristics of a theoretic dynamical phenomenon called coexistence, along with its disruption under perturbation, were examined.  Compared to cyclic stiffness only, the addition of cyclic damping usually has a destabilizing effect, but specific combinations may be slightly stabilizing.  We built an experiment to observe parametric excitation effects.

BROADER IMPACTS: 

Understanding vibrations and dynamic loads is imperative for designing wind turbines for longer lifetimes, lower-cost maintenance, and improved reliability.  The benefit to society is a more robust and reliable wind-energy contingent, which will help reduce overall energy costs and contribute to reduction of greenhouse gas emissions.  To increase energy production, there is a trust to continue increasing turbine size and move off shore, both of which present structural challenges to the reliability of the turbines.  The work will be significant to the design of such turbines.  The beam-based model is amenable to substructure coupling with the tower and platform, and will therefore contribute to follow-up studies on whole land-based and off-shore turbine structures.  Studies of parametric damping and stiffness were motivated by the turbine blades, but are also of general interest in the dynamical systems community.

This work involved the training of a primary doctoral student, who has developed expertise in dynamical modeling and analysis that can be applied in the future to renewable energy research and development.  This student is expected to complete the doctoral degree during 2020.  Another doctoral student has been involved in a secondary supporting role.  Both students are female, and thus the project has helped to broaden the diversity of the advanced-degree workforce.  This work resulted in several conference papers and presentations including a keynote, a submitted journal paper with several more journal papers in preparation, and the PhD thesis of the primary doctoral student.  The project had an outreach component in which the principal investigator and graduate students presented annually to aspiring high-school students about mechanical engineering and current energy challenges, and included a hands-on opportunity with a mini-wind-turbine kit to design blades and then systematically change design parameters to observe their effects on electricity generation.
